description: Nikola Petrak quietly suppresses all planned citywide Council broadcasts, redirecting system privileges to block mass communication. Local networks are left open for citizen use.
With official channels silent, citizens seize the moment: a spontaneous festival erupts in the city center, featuring music, art, performances, and games that openly mock BCI compliance routines.

Festivals and public celebrations spread to outlying districts as community leaders encourage creativity, myth-making, and open resistance. The Council condemns the gatherings but is ignored by the swelling crowds.
Hacked BCI prompts become playful challenges. Residents form 'forgiveness circles,' manipulate their own scores, and support marginalized groups as new community trust replaces algorithmic authority.
Stenograd unites through celebration and collective defiance. The Council's authority collapses; past compliance records are publicly destroyed as citizens embrace a new spirit of self-determination.
